newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq ratifies rice accord with Vietnam - papers.
newsitem.headline: Iraq ratifies rice accord with Vietnam - papers.

text.p: Iraqi newspapers said on Monday that a cabinet meeting chaired by President Saddam Hussein had ratified an agreement with Vietnam to improve rice cultivation in Iraq.
"The Council of Ministers...ratified an agreement to improve rice cultivation in Iraq signed with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam," the newspapers said.

A Vietnamese embassy source in Baghdad said an accord was signed between the two countries during a visit to Hanoi last March by Iraq's agriculture minister. The source said Hanoi would send experts on rice production to Iraq and would also provide Iraq with seeds as well as train Iraqis in Vietnam.
Iraq's agricultural output, according to U.N. estimates, does not meet one fourth of demand even during bumper harvests.
Iraq meets most of its needs for rice, estimated at about one million tonnes a year, through imports from either Pakistan, Vietnam or Thailand.
Last year the Vietnamese embassy said Hanoi signed a deal with Baghdad to supply Iraq with 200,000 tonnes of rice in 1996.

Each Iraqi is entitled to 1.25 kg of rice a month, part of the meagre food basket distributed by the government at giveaway prices. In the commercial market one kg of rice costs about one third of a civil servant's monthly salary.

Since 1990, when sanctions were imposed on Iraq for invading Kuwait, Vietnam has supplied Iraq with a yearly average of 50,000 metric tonnes of rice and 4,000 metric tonnes black tea, the embassy source said.
Before the sanctions there were about 60,000 Vietnamese workers in Iraq.
